questions.text: Beta 2 receptor action leading to hyperglycemia/hypoglycemia is mediated by which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Pathway

Mechanism

cAMP/PKA Pathway

Activation of β2-AR by catecholamines or β2-agonists couples with Gs protein.Increases cAMP and activates PKA.PKA phosphorylates proteins regulating glucose metabolism.

mTORC2 Pathway

Chronic β2-AR stimulation promotes glucose uptake via mTORC2.Enhances GLUT4 translocation to the muscle cell membrane, independent of insulin signaling.

Condition

Effect

Mechanism

Hyperglycemia

Acute β2-AR stimulation increases blood glucose levels.

Promotes hepatic glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.Stimulates insulin secretion from beta cells.

Hypoglycemia

Chronic β2-AR stimulation lowers blood glucose levels.

Increases skeletal muscle glucose uptake via mTORC2-mediated GLUT4 translocation.Improves glucose tolerance.

Counterregulatory Mechanism

Restores glucose during hypoglycemia or fasting.

Stimulates hepatic glucose production.Inhibits insulin action in peripheral tissues.

Kidney

questions.text: Which cells are impacted in multiple sclerosis?

What is the most probable diagnosis for a 20-year-old male patient who has been experiencing lower backache and morning stiffness for two years, along with bilateral heel pain for the past six months?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton (spine and sacroiliac joints), leading to pain, stiffness, and spinal fusion (bamboo spine).

Etiology

Idiopathic; genetic (HLA-B27) and environmental factors involved. HLA-B27 is positive in 90% of cases, but not all carriers develop AS.

Pathophysiology

Inflammation at entheses → Erosive changes → New bone formation → Syndesmophytes → Spinal fusion (ankylosis).

Clinical Features

Musculoskeletal Symptoms:

  • Chronic low back pain (worse after inactivity, better with activity)
  • Limited spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (Achilles, plantar fascia)
  • Peripheral arthritis (hips, shoulders, knees)

Extra-articular Symptoms:

  • Ocular: Anterior uveitis (pain, redness, photophobia)
  • Cardiovascular: Aortic regurgitation, conduction issues
  • Pulmonary: Apical fibrosis
  • Gastrointestinal: Associated with IBD

Clinical tests:

  • Schober/ Modified Schober test (for lumbar spine)
  • Gaenslen’s test
  • Patrick/FABER test
  • Figure of 4 test
  • Pump handle test

Diagnosis

Based on clinical features, imaging studies, and HLA-B27 gene presence. Modified New York Criteria:

Clinical Criteria:

  • Low back pain > 3 months (improves with exercise, not with rest)
  • Limited lumbar spine motion (sagittal/frontal planes)
  • Reduced chest expansion (relative to age/sex)

Radiographic Criteria (X-ray):

  • Bilateral sacroiliitis (grade 2-4) or unilateral sacroiliitis (grade 3-4)

Radiological Features:

  • Blurring/haziness of sacroiliac joint
  • Squaring of vertebrae
  • Bamboo spine
  • Dagger sign

 

MRI: Early detection of inflammation

Laboratory Tests
  • HLA-B27 positive (90% of cases)
  • ESR, CRP: Elevated during active disease, but can be normal

Treatment

Non-Pharmacological:

  • Physical therapy (mobility/posture exercises)
  • Patient education on disease and exercise importance

Pharmacological:

  • NSAIDs (first-line for pain, stiffness)
  • TNF inhibitors/IL-17 inhibitors (Secukinumab)
  • Sulfasalazine (for peripheral arthritis)
  • Corticosteroids (short-term flare control)

Surgical:

  • Hip replacement (for severe hip involvement)
  • Spinal surgery (for severe deformities/fractures)

Complications
  • Spinal fractures (minimal trauma)
  • Cardiac issues (aortic regurgitation, conduction defects)
  • Osteoporosis leading to fracture risk

questions.text: A 28-year old male with gradual progressive swelling around his wrist joint for 3 months. Image of the swelling on the x-ray film is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Benign but locally aggressive tumor of bone.
  • It commonly arises from epiphysis.
  • MC Age: 20 and 45 years of age.
  • Females > males.

Sites affected
  • Distal femur > proximal tibia > distal radius > sacrum.

Malignancy
  • Malignant transformation in <1% of cases.
  • Lungs are the most common site for metastases.

Clinical features
  • Swelling, vague pain.
  • Pathological fracture.

Radiology
  • X-ray: Expansile eccentric lytic lesion on epiphysis

Histo- pathology
  • Multinucleated giant cells and a background network of spindle-shaped mononuclear stromal cells.

 

Management
  • Extended curettage with Bone grafting

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who is brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident, complaining of pain around the left hip joint, and is found to have a flexed, adducted, and internally rotated affected limb with noticeable shortening?
questions.explanation:
Posterior dislocation of hip (Option B)

Anterior dislocation of hip (Option A)

Central fracture-dislocation of hip (Option C)

Mechanism of injury:

  • Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

  • Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Mechanism of injury:

  • The femoral head is driven through the medial wall of the acetabulum into the pelvic cavity.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

Clinical features:

  • Varying displacement is seen.
  • Joint stiffness and osteoarthritis are very likely.

questions.text: A patient presented with joint pain and on evaluation, urine turns black on standing. What is the likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A: Homogentisic acid 1,2-dioxygenase

1. Homogentisic Aciduria

Presence of homogentisic acid in the urine, which turns dark upon standing or when exposed to air.

2. Ochronosis

Deposition of dark pigment in connective tissues, particularly noticeable in the ear cartilage, sclera, and other connective tissues, leading to a bluish-black discoloration.The image shows Osler’s sign.

3. Arthropathy

Degenerative joint disease, especially affecting the spine and large joints, leading to chronic pain and stiffness.

4. Cardiac Involvement

Includes heart valve calcification and atherosclerosis due to the deposition of pigment in cardiac tissues.

Reaction

Asymptomatic phase; the virus multiplies in the respiratory tract, followed by primary and secondary viremia.

Prodromal Stage

4 days
  • Fever (day 10),
  • Koplik’s spots (day 12),
  • non-specific symptoms (cough, coryza, conjunctivitis).

Eruptive Stage

4 days post fever

The maculopapular rash appears first behind the ears, then spreads to the face, trunk, and limbs, fading in the same order.

Post-measles Stage

Variable

Characterized by weight loss, weakness, and a risk of progressing to chronic conditions.

questions.text: A patient admitted following a road traffic accident has left a blood spill on the hospital floor. Which disinfectant is most appropriate for effectively decontaminating the area?
questions.explanation:
Step

Action

Details

1. PPE

Wear Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

Gloves, goggles/face shield, gown/apron, mask (if necessary) to protect from exposure.

2. Control the Spill Area

Secure and contain the spill

Alert others, prevent access, and use absorbent materials (e.g., paper towels) to contain the spill.

3. Select and Apply Disinfectant

Use appropriate disinfectant

Sodium hypochlorite (1%) is preferred. Apply disinfectant to the spill and allow it to sit for 10 minutes.

4. Clean the Spill

Wipe the area with absorbent materials

Use disposable towels or wipes to clean up the blood and dispose of them in biohazard waste.

5. Disinfect Surrounding Area

Clean the surrounding floor or surfaces

Mop or wipe down the surrounding area with disinfectant to ensure thorough decontamination.

6. Dispose of Contaminated Items

Safely dispose of contaminated materials

Place used gloves, mop heads, towels, and any contaminated materials in a biohazard waste container.

7. Remove and Dispose of PPE

Safely remove PPE and dispose of it

Remove gloves last, ensuring that they are turned inside out. Dispose of PPE in biohazard waste containers.

8. Wash Hands

Clean hands thoroughly after cleaning

Wash hands with soap and water, or use alcohol-based hand sanitizer if soap is unavailable.

9. Documentation and Reporting

Record the incident and inform relevant departments

Document the blood spill and cleaning procedure, and report any potential exposures to infection control.

questions.text: What is the probable causative agent involved in the case of two individuals from a group of 20 friends who experienced nausea and vomiting in the early morning after consuming pastries from an external source during a late-night party?
questions.explanation:
Disease caused by Staphylococcus aureus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts
  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion (Option A)

Virulence factors

Key features

Cell wall-associated polymers

 

Peptidoglycan

 

Activates complement-induced release of inflammatory cytokines

Teichoic acid

Adherence to the host cell surface, and shields them from complement-mediated opsonization

Capsular polysaccharide

Inhibits opsonization

Cell surface

Protein A
  • Anti-complementary
  • Anti-phagocytic
  • Co-agglutination

Clumping factor

Responsible for the slide coagulase test

Toxins

Hemolysin

Alpha hemolysin-

  • Lyse sheep and human red blood cells.
  • Toxic to macrophages, lysosomes, muscle tissues, the renal cortex, and the circulatory system

Beta-hemolysins or sphingomyelinase

  • Lyse sheep red blood cells only

Panton-Valentine (PVL) Leucocidin
  • Synergohymenotropic toxin
  • Attacks neutrophils, platelets
  • Produced by Methicillin-Resistant Staph. aureus (MRSA)

Enterotoxin (superantigen)
  • Food poisoning
  • Most cases are caused by type A.
  • It acts directly on the autonomic nervous system causing symptoms. Vomiting is stimulated in the brain stem.

Toxic shock syndrome toxin(TSST) (superantigen)
  • Fatal multisystem disease
  • Tampon-related TSS

Epidermolytic/Exfoliative toxin
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): the outer layer of the epidermis gets separated from the underlying tissues.
  • Severe form of SSSS: Ritter's disease in the newborn and toxic epidermal necrolysis in older patients.
  • Milder forms: pemphigus neonatorum and bullous impetigo

Enzymes

Coagulase

Clotting of human or rabbit plasma

Lipid hydrolases

Helps in skin and subcutaneous tissue infections

Hyaluronidase
  • Breaks down the connective tissues
  • Staphylokinase, protease

Nuclease

Heat-stable DNase

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, a second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and a third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Criteria

Laboratory Criteria

Obstetrical:

  • ≥3 unexplained consecutive spontaneous miscarriages < 10 weeks gestation
  • ≥1 unexplained fetal death(s) ≥10weeks' gestation
  • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency necessitating delivery before 34 weeks

Vascular:

  • ≥1 episode of arterial, venous, or small-vessel thrombosis in any tissue
  • Presence of lupus anticoagulant (ISTH guidelines)
  • Medium/high serum levels of IgG or IgM anticardiolipin antibodies
  • Anti-β2 glycoprotein-I IgG or IgM antibody

APS Subtype

Antithrombotic Therapy

APS with prior thrombosis
  • Start therapeutic LMWH after confirming intrauterine pregnancy. (40 mg enoxaparin daily.)
  • Begin low-dose aspirin (LDA) before or immediately upon pregnancy confirmation. (60 to 80 mg daily)
  • Avoid oral anticoagulants and factor Xa inhibitors throughout pregnancy.

APS with pregnancy morbidity but no prior thrombosis
  • Prophylactic-dose LMWH or unfractionated heparin upon confirmation of pregnancy,
  • LDA (81 mg) as early as possible.

Patients with early or late pregnancy loss
  • Prophylactic-dose LMWH or unfractionated heparin,
  • LDA (81 mg) from before pregnancy or as soon as known

Preeclampsia with severe features or placental insufficiency
  • LDA from before pregnancy or as soon as known,
  • Consider LMWH in specific cases

Hydroxychloroquine: For recurrent pregnancy loss despite standard therapy.

IVIG and Prednisone: For refractory cases to reduce recurrent pregnancy loss; low-dose prednisone is preferred to minimise maternal and fetal risks.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient came with a history of fatiguability and constipation for the past 1 year. She had a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago. She has had a lactational failure and never regained her periods after the delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Postpartum hypopituitarism caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Symptoms
  • Failure to lactate
  • Hypotension
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Fatigue
  • Amenorrhea
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Adrenal insufficiency
  • Decreased libido
  • Weight gain
  • Cold intolerance

Diagnosis
  • Clinical history of severe postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Hormonal evaluation: Low levels of pituitary hormones (prolactin, TSH, ACTH, LH, FSH, growth hormone).
  • MRI: Empty sella or reduced pituitary size.

Treatment:

Lifelong hormone replacement therapy (glucocorticoids, levothyroxine, estrogen-progesterone, growth hormone if needed)

questions.text: A patient was suspected of having acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially, but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test?
questions.explanation:
Morphology

Biochemical Properties

Growth & Susceptibility

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli

Catalase positive

Do not grow well on standard laboratory media

Non-capsulated and non-spore forming

Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis)

Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 minutes

Often exhibit a bipolar staining appearance

Urease positive

Killed by 1% phenol in 15 minutes
 

Utilize oxygen but do not typically ferment carbohydrates

Killed by pasteurization

Test

Description

Key Points

Standard Agglutination Test (SAT)

Tube agglutination test using serial dilutions of patient's serum and killed B. abortus antigen
  • Significant titer: 160 or more.
  • Acute brucellosis titer: 640 or more within 3-4 weeks.
  • Prozone phenomenon common.
  • False positives with cholera, tularemia, yersinia infection, or immunization

Complement Fixation Test

Detects IgG antibodies
  • Valuable in chronic cases

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)

Distinguishes between IgM and IgG antibodies
  • Useful for differentiating acute from chronic infections

Rapid Tests

Includes rapid dipstick tests and Rose Bengal card test
  • Quick results.
  • Can be used for initial screening

Characteristic

Details

Morphology

Small, non-motile, aerobic, Gram-negative coccobacilli, Non-capsulated, non-spore forming, Bipolar staining

Biochemical Properties

Catalase positive, Oxidase positive (except B. neotomae and B. ovis), Urease positive, Utilize oxygen, do not ferment carbohydrates

Growth & Susceptibility

Do not grow well on standard media. Destroyed by heat at 60°C in 10 min, Killed by 1% phenol in 15 min, Killed by pasteurization.

Zoonotic Nature

Affects goats, sheep, cattle, buffaloes, pigs. Human infection through contact or consumption.

Symptoms

Intermittent fever, loss of appetite, nausea, muscular and articular pains, fatigue, sweating, joint pain.

Blood Culture

Trypticase soy broth or brucella broth. Biphasic blood culture (Castaneda method). Large blood volume (5 ml). Incubation: 37°C, 5-10% CO2, 6-8 weeks. 30-50% positive cases. Bone marrow cultureshave a higher yield.

Serological Tests

SAT: Significant titer 160+, Acute 640+, Complement Fixation: IgG detection, ELISA: Distinguishes IgM & IgG. Rapid Tests: Dipstick, Rose Bengal

Antibiotics

Adults: Doxycycline 45 days, Streptomycin 2 weeks, Children: Cotrimoxazole + Rifampicin/Gentamycin.

Vaccination

No human vaccine, Occupational risk: Attenuated live vaccine, Animals: B. abortus strain 19 vaccine.

He says that he has been having a nocturnal cough for the last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. questions.explanation:
Rhabditiform larva

Filariform larva

1st stage of the larva (L1).

3d stage of the larva (L3).

Formed when eggs hatch in the small intestine.

Developed from two molts of the L1 larva.

Measures approximately 0.25 mm in length with a short muscul’ar double-bulb esophagus.

Measures about 0.55 mm in length, characterized by a long, slender shape, uniform esophagus & notched tail.

Found in feces.

Seen in hyperinfection & disseminated infection may show in sputum, stool and body fluids.

Diagnostic form

Infective form

Pathogenesis and Clinical Features of Strongyloides Stercoralis Infection

Effect of Migrating Larvae
  • Asymptomatic Infection: Over 50% may be asymptomatic.
  • Rashes: Recurrent maculopapular or urticarial rashes on buttocks, perineum, and thighs.
  • Cutaneous Larva Migrans: Serpiginous rash (larva currens) advancing up to 10 cm/hour.
  • Pulmonary Symptoms: Rare, mainly in chronic obstructive lung disease.

Effects of Adult Worms & Filariform Larvae
  • Mild to Moderate Load: Epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, and blood loss.
  • Heavy Larval Load: Risk of hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Hyperinfection Syndrome
  • Cause: Repeated autoinfection leads to increased filariform larvae.
  • Risk Factors: Glucocorticoid therapy, immunosuppressive conditions, HTLV-1/HIV coinfection.
  • Features: Colitis, enteritis, malabsorption, possible progression to disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Disseminated Strongyloidiasis
  • Pathophysiology: Larvae invade GIT and other organs. Disrupted mucosa may allow enteric flora to cause bacterial sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis.
  • Clinical Manifestations: CNS invasion, brain abscesses, meningitis; larvae in CSF. Eosinophilia, often absent in severe cases.
  • Mortality Rate: Nearing 100% untreated; over 25% even with treatment.



 

Laboratory Diagnosis

Stool Microscopy: Rhabditiform larvae; requires multiple samples (4+) for accurate diagnosis.

Microscopy of Other Specimens: Entero-test for duodenal aspirates; high filariform larvae are found in stool, sputum, and tissue biopsies for disseminated cases.

Stool Culture: Differentiates rhabditiform from hookworm larvae.

Serology: ELISA for antibodies; may show cross-reactivity, less effective for recent infections.

Coproantigen Detection: Antigen capture ELISA specific to Strongyloides.

Molecular Diagnosis: Real-time PCR targeting specific genes.

Treatment
  • Asymptomatic Treatment: Strongyloidiasis should be treated regardless of symptoms due to the risk of hyperinfection.
  • Ivermectin (200 mg/kg daily for 2 days)

questions.text: One week after having unprotected sexual intercourse, a 25-year-old male develops urethral discharge as shown in the image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Neisseria Gonorrhoeae

Clinical Features

Men

Urethritis, purulent urethral discharge, dysuria, epididymitis, prostatitis.

Women

Cervicitis, vaginal discharge, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), dysuria, and intermenstrual bleeding.

Rarely can cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

Pharyngeal Infection

Often asymptomatic, sore throat, pharyngitis.

Rectal Infection

Proctitis, rectal discharge, pain, and tenesmus, may be asymptomatic.

Disseminated Gonococcal Infection (DGI)

Fever, dermatitis, polyarthralgia, septic arthritis.

Neonates

Ophthalmia neonatorum, conjunctivitis, potential for blindness if untreated.

Diagnosis

Gram Stain

Gram-negative diplococci within polymorphonuclear leukocytes (particularly useful in men).

Culture

Thayer-Martin or other selective media, oxidase-positive, and carbohydrate utilization tests.

NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test)

Highly sensitive and specific, recommended for urogenital, pharyngeal, and rectal specimens.

Serological Tests

Not commonly used due to lower sensitivity and specificity compared to NAAT and culture.

Treatment- Green STD kit

First-Line Therapy

Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose PLUS doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily for 7 days (if chlamydial co-infection is not excluded).

Alternative Therapy

Gentamicin 240 mg IM as a single dose PLUS azithromycin 2 g orally as a single dose (if ceftriaxone is not available).

questions.text: Which of the following is assessed by evaluating the patient's treatment and clinical management in a healthcare facility?
questions.explanation:
Evaluation Type

Description

Focus

Purpose

Structure Evaluation (Option C ruled out)

Assesses the resources and organizational components of healthcare facilities.

Infrastructure, staff qualifications, medical equipment

Ensure the healthcare facility has adequate resources, equipment, and trained staff.

Process Evaluation

Assesses how healthcare services are delivered, focusing on procedures and practices.

Clinical guidelines, care delivery methods, patient interactions

Ensure care is aligned with best practices and protocols.

Outcome Evaluation (Option A ruled out)

Evaluates the results of healthcare interventions.

Health outcomes, symptom improvement, recovery, patient satisfaction

Determine the effectiveness of treatments and interventions in improving health.

Input Evaluation (Option D ruled out)

Assesses the resources available for healthcare.

Financial resources, staff levels, medical supplies

Ensure sufficient resources for effective healthcare delivery.

Cost-Effectiveness Evaluation

Assesses whether the intervention provides good value for the cost.

Cost relative to health outcomes, alternative treatments

Ensure the efficient use of resources and value for money in healthcare.

Patient-Centered Evaluation

Focuses on patient experience and satisfaction.

Patient satisfaction, provider-patient relationship, treatment understanding

Ensure care aligns with patient needs and improves their experience and compliance.

Component

Definition

Key Focus Areas

Relevance

Assesses whether the program addresses the priority health needs of the target population.

Disease burden, target group needs, alignment with public health goals.

Adequacy

Evaluates whether the resources and scale of the program are sufficient to achieve the intended outcomes.

Coverage, resource allocation, unmet needs.

Accessibility

Measures how easily beneficiaries can access program services.

Geographic, financial, and cultural barriers to access.

Acceptability

Determines whether the program is acceptable to beneficiaries and stakeholders.

Community participation, cultural compatibility, stakeholder feedback.

Equity

Assesses whether the program reduces disparities in health outcomes and services.

Reach among marginalized populations, fairness in resource distribution.

Efficiency

Evaluates the optimal use of resources to achieve desired outcomes.

Cost-efficiency, time management, operational performance.

Effectiveness

Measures the extent to which the program achieves its objectives and desired outcomes.

Reduction in morbidity and mortality, behavior changes, program goals met.

questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge?
What is the vector that causes the occurrence of buboes in the community?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Vector

Identification

Habitat

Details

Malaria

Female Anopheles mosquito (Option D ruled out)

 

Slender body, long legs, and dark-colored spots on wings.

Stagnant, clean water sources like ponds, lakes, and rice fields.

Transmits Plasmodium species causing malaria.

Dengue

Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus

Aedes aegypti

White markings on legs, lyre-shaped pattern on the thorax.

Urban areas, especially around human dwellings and discarded containers.

Transmits Dengue virus causing dengue fever.

 

Chikungunya

Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus

Aedes albopictus

Similar to Aedes mosquitoes, with black and white banded legs.

Urban and suburban areas, especially in domestic settings.

Transmits Chikungunya virus, causing joint pain.

Japanese Encephalitis

Culex mosquito

Smaller, brown or black, with a distinct scutellum (plate-like structure).

Ponds, marshes, and areas with stagnant water.

Transmits Japanese encephalitis virus, causing encephalitis.

Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar)

Phlebotomus argentipes (sandfly) (Option B ruled out)

Small, yellowish-brown, with a hairy body and long legs.

Sandy, dusty areas, often near human dwellings or animal shelters.

Transmits Leishmania species causing visceral leishmaniasis.

Bubonic Plague

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea)

Small, reddish-brown, flattened body.

Found on rats, especially in urban areas and during rodent infestations.

Transmits Yersinia pestis causing bubonic plague.

Filariasis

Female Culex mosquito

Similar to Anopheles but with more rounded body and darker markings.

Stagnant water, especially in urban and rural areas.

Transmits Wuchereria bancrofti causing lymphatic filariasis.

Zika Virus

Aedes mosquitoes

Aedes albopictus

Similar to Aedes aegypti, black and white striped legs.

Urban and suburban areas, particularly in places with standing water.

Transmits Zika virus causing fever and birth defects.

Tick-borne Encephalitis

Ixodes tick (Option C ruled out)

Small, oval-shaped, with a flattened body.

Forested areas, grasslands, and areas with high animal populations.

Transmits Tick-borne encephalitis virus causing encephalitis.

Rickettsial Diseases

Rhipicephalus (dog tick) and other ticks

Oval, flat, with prominent mouthparts.

Grasslands, forests, and around domesticated animals.

Transmits Rickettsia bacteria causing typhus, scrub typhus, etc.

Malaria (P. falciparum)

Female Anopheles mosquito (Option D ruled out)

 

Same as malaria vector.

Found in areas with stagnant water and human proximity.

Responsible for severe malaria (Plasmodium falciparum).

Scrub Typhus

Leptotrombidium mites (chiggers)

 

Small, red, and often barely visible to the naked eye.

Rural and semi-rural areas with dense vegetation.

Transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi causing scrub typhus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been complaining of fatigue for the past year. The examination revealed massive splenomegaly. His blood workup shows the presence of anemia, TLC 150,000/microL, and PBS shows 60% neutrophils, 6% basophils, 4% eosinophils, myeloblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. The myeloid-to-erythroid ratio was 18:1. Which of the following is the most sensitive investigation in this case?
questions.explanation:
Investigations to find CML

CBC
  • Normal RBC + Elevated TLC + Elevated platelets

Peripheral smear
  • Left shift with predominant segmented neutrophils, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes.
  • College girl/garden party appearance.

Bone marrow aspirate
  • Increased Myeloid: Erythroid ratio.
  • Dwarf megakaryocytes.
  • Sea blue histiocytes (blue-coloured cytoplasm)
  • Pseudo Gaucher cells

NAP/LAP score

The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is low in CML and can be used to differentiate it from other leukaemias, but it’s not the most sensitive test. (Option B ruled out)

FISH (IOC)
  • Confirms t(9:22) translocation.
  • Analysis to quantify Philadelphia chromosome-positive cells.
  • Estimates the tumour load.

PCR

  • To quantify BCR-ABL-1.
  • It can be a false negative or a false positive.
  • False negative: Early part of the disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Take 1 pill now, continue the schedule, and use a barrier method of contraception

options.label: C
options.text: Take 1 pill now, use a barrier method, and consider emergency contraception in case of recent intercourse

options.label: D
options.text: Discard the pack and start a new pack with an alternate method of contraception

questions.correct_answer: D. Discard the pack and start a new pack with an alternate method of contraception
questions.explanation:
Number of Pills Missed

Timing of Missed Pills

Management

Additional Considerations

1 Pill

Anytime
  • Take the missed pill as soon as remembered and continue the rest at the usual time ( Take two pills in one day).

No additional contraception is needed. Emergency contraception (EC) is not required.

2 Consecutive Pills

Week 1 or Week 2
  • Take the most recent missed pill as soon as remembered ( Take two pills in one day) and continue the rest as usual.
  • Use backup contraception (e.g., condoms) for 7 days.

Consider EC if missed during Week 1 and unprotected sex occurred in the previous 5 days.

2 Consecutive Pills

Week 3 or Week 4
  • Discard the current pack and start a new pack immediately.
  • Use backup contraception for 7 days.

_

3 or More Consecutive Pills

Anytime
  • Discard the current pack and start a new pack immediately.
  • Use backup contraception for 7 days.

_

A 40-year-old male presents with complaints of episodes of palpitations, headache, and profuse sweating for the past few days. MIBG scan shows a deep-seated tumour in the adrenal medulla. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition described?

options.text: Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension

options.label: D
options.text: Can present as hypertension alone and sometimes with vomiting and pain abdomen

questions.correct_answer: C. Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension
questions.explanation:
Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • The dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Vomiting (Option D)
  • Pain abdomen
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines (Option A)
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines
  • Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) (a metabolite of adrenaline and noradrenaline) (Option A)

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection. (Option B)
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers (phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight) (vs Option C)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of atherosclerosis underwent a circumflex artery bypass. The stent is now placed successfully. He's already taking lisinopril, verapamil, and metoprolol. Which drug should be added?
questions.explanation:
Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI)

PCI involves balloon dilatation and stenting for symptomatic IHD with suitable stenoses in epicardial coronary arteries.

  • Indications:
    • Symptom-limiting angina despite optimal medical therapy.
    • Evidence of ischemia during stress tests.
  • Post-PCI Management:
    • Aspirin is administered indefinitely, and P2Y12 antagonists for 1-3 months.
    • P2Y12 receptor antagonists are used with aspirin for up to 12 months.
      • Clopidogrel (300mg, followed by 75 mg daily) with aspirin reduces death, reinfarction, and stroke risks in STEMI patients.
      • Newer drugs like ticagrelor (180 mg, followed by 90 mg twice daily) and prasugrel (60 mg, followed by 10 mg daily) are more effective than clopidogrel for ischemic complication prevention in STEMI patients undergoing PCI but have a higher bleeding risk.
    • Current-generation drug-eluting stents reduce restenosis but require prolonged dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT).

Main Causes

  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Lupus erythematosus (LE)
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
  • Retinopathy associated with AIDS
  • Diabetic retinopathy (Most common cause) (Option B)

Correct Answer B - Spherical equivalent spectacles

Optical

  • Rigid contact lenses: for up to 3D
  • Toric contact lenses: for > 3D astigmatism cases

Refractive Procedures

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with a fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest x-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

Atypical Pneumonia

Outpatients

Hospitalised Patients

Includes M.pneumoniae C.pneumoniae, and Legionella species.

Common causes:

S.pneumoniae, M.pneumoniae

H. influenzae, C.pneumoniae, Respiratory viruses (influenza, RSV).

Non-ICU

ICU Patients

Similar pathogens to outpatients, plus Legionella species.

Pathogens include S.pneumoniae, S. aureus (including MRSA), Legionella species, gram-negative bacilli, and H. influenzae.

Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA):
  • It can cause CAP, often complicating influenza infections.
  • Community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) has emerged as a significant cause of necrotizing pneumonia.

Pneumococcal Pneumonia:
  • Higher risk in elderly patients, and those with comorbidities like dementia, heart failure, cerebrovascular disease, alcoholism, smoking, COPD, and HIV infection.

CA-MRSA Pneumonia:
  • More likely in patients with prior skin infections or following viral illnesses.

Enterobacteriaceae:
  • Common in patients recently hospitalized, those treated with antibiotics, or those with comorbidities like alcoholism, heart failure, or renal failure.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
  • Found in patients with severe structural lung diseases such as bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, or advanced COPD.

Legionella Infection:
  • Associated with risk factors like diabetes, hematologic malignancies, cancer, severe renal disease, HIV, smoking, male gender, and recent travel (air conditioners, showers, hotels, cruise ships). It is an important cause of atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: In a patient, a 33-year-old female presents with symptoms of gradual vision loss specifically affecting the right halves of both eyes. The question pertains to the location of the lesion in the optic pathway.
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Left optic tract

Components of Visual Pathway

Retina
  • First-order Neurons: Bipolar cells in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
  • Second-order Neurons: Ganglion cells in the retina; their axons form the optic nerve.

Optic Nerve
  • Carries visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm.
  • Temporal and Nasal fibres of the same eye.

Optic Chiasma
  • Partial decussation occurs
  • Nasal fibres cross to the opposite side, while temporal fibres remain ipsilateral.

Optic Tract
  • Carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the Lateral Geniculate body (LGB).
  • Temporal fibres of the same eye and Nasal fibres of the opposite eye.

Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)
  • Third Order Neurons: Relay visual information to the visual cortex.

Optic Radiations
  • Meyer's Loop: Carries information from lower retinal quadrants to the inferior part of the visual cortex.
  • Baum’s Loop (Dorsal): Carries information from upper retinal quadrants to the superior part of the visual cortex.

Occipital Cortex
  • The primary visual cortex (V1), corresponding to Brodmann area 17, is situated on the medial side of the occipital lobe, particularly along the borders of the calcarine fissure.

Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

 

Anopia (Option D)

Optic Chiasma

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

Bitemporal Hemianopia

(Heteronymous Hemianopia) (Option C)

Optic Tract/ Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)/ Optic Radiation

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers

Homonymous Hemianopia

Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip

(Posterior Cerebral Artery)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation

Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing

(Option B)

Tip of Visual Cortex

(Middle Cerebral Artery)

Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers.

Macular Homonymous Hemianopia

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 2-month-old infant who was brought in by their mother due to complaints of light sensitivity, difficulty opening the eyes, and excessive tearing?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Congenital glaucoma:

Types
  1. Newborn glaucoma/ True congenital glaucoma: Elevated intraocular pressure is present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth. Typically presents within the first month of life.
  2. Infantile: ≤ 3 yrs of age
  3. Juvenile: > 3 yrs of age

Pathogenesis
  • Trabeculodysgenesis
  • Angle Recess Absence
  • Iris Insertion Types:
    • Flat Insertion: Reveals the ciliary body and scleral spur.
    • Concave Insertion: Obscures the scleral spur and ciliary body.

Clinical Features
  • Classic Triad: Lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm; often accompanied by eye rubbing.
  • Corneal Signs:
    • Oedema: Early sign, may progress to permanent opacity.
    • Enlargement: Corneal diameter >13 mm confirms enlargement; >16 mm indicates poor prognosis.
  • Haab’s Striae: Tears in Descemet's membrane, visible as opaque lines.
  • Additional Features:
    • Deep Anterior Chamber: Indicates elevated IOP.
    • Optic Disc Changes: Variable cupping and atrophy.
    • Raised IOP: Elevated but not acute.
    • Axial Myopia: Due to increased axial length.

Management

Direct Goniotomy followed by Trabeculotomy - preferred management for Congenital Glaucoma

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Methotrexate in Osteosarcoma?
The person in the image is at the risk of developing?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Exposure keratopathy

Iris Coloboma
  • Pear-shaped defect extending from the pupil but not always reaching the ciliary body. It may occur alone or be associated with colobomata of the lens, choroid, or retina.

Coloboma of lens
  • Notch-shaped defect typically found along the inferior lens margin due to incomplete development of the suspensory ligament.

Fundus Coloboma
  • Oval or comet-shaped defect with a rounded apex toward the optic disc, often with an irregularly depressed surface.

Coloboma of Optic Disc
  • It appears as an inferior crescent at the lower edge of the disc due to incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure.
  • Found in Hypermetropic and Astigmatic eyes.

Coloboma of Lid
  • Notch or gap in the eyelid edge, most commonly on the upper lid, often associated with iris coloboma or accessory auricles.
  • The corneal surface cannot stay lubricated and hence can lead to exposure keratopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs should not be consumed by a patient with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis currently on metronidazole?
questions.explanation:
Metronidazole

MOA
  • Prodrug is converted to active form through nitro group reduction inside the bacteria → formation of nitric oxide free radicals → causes DNA damage → inhibits replication.
  • Inhibits PFOR enzyme (pyruvate ferritin oxido reductase) in protozoa → DNA damage.

Uses

  • Giardiasis (in HIV-positive patients)
  • Entamoeba histolytica → Amebic dysentery & amebic liver abscess
  • Trichomonas vaginalis
  • Bacterial Vaginosis
  • Dracunculus (guinea worm)
  • Gardenella / bacterial vaginosis
  • Empiric intra-abdominal and soft tissue anaerobic infections
  • H. pylori gastritis (combined with proton pump inhibitor)
  • Prophylaxis for colorectal surgery
  • Fulminant C.difficile infection (IV metronidazole + oral vancomycin)
  • Mild to moderate Crohn's disease

Adverse effects
  • Metallic taste, intensely bitter
  • Headache, nausea, dry mouth (most common)
  • Vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal distress
  • Dysuria, cystitis, and a sense of pelvic pressure
  • Dizziness, vertigo,
  • Neurotoxicity: Peripheral neuropathy, numbness, paresthesias, ataxia
  • Brown color urine
  • Urticaria, flushing, and pruritus ( rare cause of Stevens-Johnson syndrome)

Drug Interaction
  • Inhibitor of CYP enzymes
  • Disulfiram-like effect: abdominal distress, vomiting, flushing, headache or psychosis with alcoholic beverages during or within 3 days of therapy.
  • Precipitate lithium toxicity
  • Prothrombin time prolongation with warfarin (anticoagulant).

Contraindications
  • CNS diseases
  • Severe hepatic disease
  • First trimester of pregnancy

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Giant papillary conjunctivitis

Definition

Specific allergic inflammation affecting the superior tarsal conjunctiva.

Etiology

  • Soft hydrophilic contact lenses
  • Protruding suture ends
  • Ocular prostheses

Underlying Mechanism

Hypersensitivity reactions (types I and IV)

Symptoms

  • Itching/ Watering
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Occasionally blurred vision

Signs

  • Conjunctival congestion predominantly in the upper palpebral region
  • Large polygonal papillae on superior tarsal conjunctiva
  • Macropapillae (0.3-1.0 mm) and giant papillae (1-2 mm)

Management

  • Discontinue soft contact lenses, remove offending sutures, clean and polish ocular prosthesis; replace with biocompatible material (e.g., Biocoat).
  • Ancillary therapy: Mast cell stabilizers (e.g., lodoxamide, cromolyn sodium, olopatadine) along with artificial tears, antihistaminic drops, and decongestants.

questions.text: A patient who was recently started on an antihypertensive presented with the following presentation, as shown in the image below. Which of the following antihypertensive medications was most likely prescribed to him?
questions.explanation:
Adverse effects of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

Hypotension

Decrease in blood pressure, especially upon initiation of therapy or with dosage increases.

Hyperkalemia

Increased serum potassium levels due to reduced aldosterone secretion.

Cough

Persistent dry cough, possibly due to bradykinin buildup in the lungs.

Angioedema

Due to increased bradykinin levels, swelling of deeper layers of skin, particularly around the eyes and lips, can be life-threatening.

Rashes/Urticaria

Skin reactions like rashes or hives occur in a small percentage of users.

Dysgeusia

Reversible taste changes are more common with captopril.

Rare Effects

Granulocytopenia (low white blood cells) and proteinuria (excess protein in urine) are more concerning in patients with kidney disease.

Acute Renal Failure

Possible in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis due to decreased kidney filtration.

Fetal Effects

ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential harm to the fetus, including fetal renal damage due to inhibition of the fetal renin-angiotensin system.

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody(ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma

Presence of Clonal plasma cells in bone marrow or presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anaemia and bone lesions)

1. Evidence of one or more indicators of end-organ damage attributed to the plasma cell disorder, specifically: (CRAB)

Hypercalcemia

Serum calcium >0.25 mmol/L above the upper limit of normal or >2.75 mmol/L (>11 mg/dL).

Renal Insufficiency:

Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >177 μmol/L (>2 mg/dL).

Anemia

Hemoglobin >20 g/L below the lower limit of normal or haemoglobin <100 g/L or <10g/100ml.

Bone Lesions:

One or more osteolytic lesions were identified on skeletal radiography, CT, or PET-CT.

2. Biomarkers of Malignancy (any one of the following):

  • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥60%.
  • Involved: uninvolved serum-free light chain ratio ≥100.
  • 1 focal lesion on MRI studies.

Poor Prognosis markers: ↑ β2 microglobulin.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with laboured breathing. ECG shows tall, tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. pH-7.14, pCO2-20 mmHg, HCO3- 5 mEq/L
questions.explanation:
Metabolic acidosis

Definition
  • Primary decrease in HCO3⁻ or increase in H⁺ ions
  • Characterized by ↓ pH and ↓ HCO3⁻
  • Compensatory mechanism: ↓ PaCO2 through hyperventilation (Kussmaul breathing)

Types

High anion gap (AG > 12 mEq/L)

Normal anion gap (AG 6-12 mEq/L)

Causes

(Mnemonic: MUDPILES)

  • M: Methanol
  • U: Uremia (Renal failure)
  • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • P: Paraldehyde, Phenformin, Propylene glycol
  • I: Iron tablets, Isoniazid
  • L: Lactic acidosis
  • E: Ethylene glycol
  • S: Salicylates (late phase)

(Mnemonic: HARD UP)

  • H: Hyperalimentation (TPN)
  • A: Acetazolamide
  • R: Renal Tubular Acidosis
  • D: Diarrhea
  • U: Ureteral diversion
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • GIT fistulas

Clinical Features

General Features:

  • Lethargy
  • Confusion
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Deep, rapid breathing (Kussmaul)

Specific Features:

  • DKA: Fruity breath, polyuria, polydipsia
  • Uremia: Itching, volume overload
  • Lactic acidosis: Shock, hypotension
  • Toxic ingestion: Visual disturbances (methanol), oxalate crystals (ethylene glycol)

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal

  • Headache

6-8 hours

  • Usually brief and self-limited

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. The general examination showed pallor, and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed a Hb level of 3 g/dl, a TLC of 1500/microL, and a platelet count of 15,000/microL. A peripheral smear shows macrocytes, and the reticulocyte count is 0.5%. A bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes with no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis?

A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (IgA vasculitis)

Definition

It is a systemic vasculitis characterised by inflammation of small blood vessels, primarily affecting children, but can also occur in adults.

Etiology

Often follows upper respiratory tract infections

Pathology

Immune complex deposition of IgA in small blood vessels leads to inflammation

Clinical features

  • Inflammation of small blood vessels primarily affects children but can also occur in adults.
  • Associated with elevated serum IgA levels
  • Skin: Palpable purpura, most prominently on the lower limbs and buttocks.
  • Musculoskeletal: Arthralgia or arthritis, often transient and non-deforming.
  • Gastrointestinal: Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes gastrointestinal bleeding, Intussusception is a severe but rare complication.
  • Renal: Hematuria, proteinuria, and red blood cell casts in urine.
  • It can progress to IgA nephropathy in severe cases.

Management

  • Supportive care: Hydration, rest, and pain management with NSAIDs for arthralgia.
  • Glucocorticoids: For severe abdominal pain, renal involvement, or systemic symptoms.
  • Intussusception: Surgical intervention if required.
  • Nephritis: Immunosuppressants (e.g., cyclophosphamide) in severe cases.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrates the proper handwashing technique to her students, who then practice it both at school and at home. What type of learning does this scenario represent?
questions.explanation:
Domains of learning

Psychomotor
  • Psychomotor learning involves acquiring physical skills and coordination through observation, practice and repetition, and the usage of motor skill areas of the brain.
  • It is measured based on speed, precision, distance and procedure in execution
  • It includes imitation, manipulation, precision, articulation and naturalisation
  • E.g., An intern learning how to insert an IV cannula by observing the staff nurse

Affective learning

(Option C)
  • Includes domain of attitude and values
  • It includes emotions, feelings, attitudes, and values
  • It encompasses the subjective experiences and expressions of emotions.
  • E.g., communicating with patients with empathy

Cognitive learning

(Option A)
  • It refers to mental processes related to knowledge acquisition, understanding, thinking, and problem-solving.
  • It involves perception, memory, attention, language, and reasoning processes.
  • E.g., Solving NEET PG entrance exam MCQs

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder?
questions.explanation:
Abnormal thought process

Derailment
  • Sudden or gradual deviation in thought (without blocking) is often used synonymously with loosening associations.

Talking Past the Point (Vorbeireden)
  • The patient responds with incorrect answers related to the topic despite understanding the question.
  • Example: Saying "white" for grass colour and "green" for snow colour.
  • Seen in hysterical pseudodementia (dissociative disorder) and Ganser’s syndrome (approximate answers).
  • It also occurs in acute schizophrenia, especially in adolescents (hebephrenia).

Loosening of Associations
  • Disorganised thought progression, shifting between unrelated topics, leading to incoherent communication.

Incoherence
  • Disconnected, disorganised, or incomprehensible speech.
  • Word Salad: Incoherent, incomprehensible mixture of words and phrases, often seen in advanced schizophrenia.

Word Approximation


 
  • Using conventional words in an unconventional way (e.g., "hand shoes" for gloves)
  • It is distinguished from a neologism, a newly created word with an unclear or unknown origin.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced by stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis?

What is the probable diagnosis for a 16-year-old girl who exhibits symptoms such as excessive familiarity, rapid flow of thoughts, heightened mood, heightened sexual desire, and experiencing pseudohallucinations?
questions.explanation:
Mania
  • Mania is a mood disorder characterised by a distinct period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and increased energy or activity levels.
  • Mania is a period of at least 1 week where a person's behaviour drastically changes and affects their functioning.
  • Individuals experiencing mania engage in heightened goal-directed activity and may show psychomotor agitation.
  • Mania is a characteristic of Bipolar I disorder.
  • Symptoms (My Asia FAST GDP)
  • M - Mood elevation
  • A - Activity levels Increased
  • F - Flight of ideas
  • A - Abnormally increased levels of activity/energy
  • S - Sleep decreased (Need for sleep is also reduced)
  • T - Talkativeness (Overtalkativeness)
  • G - Grandiose ideas and increased self-esteem
  • D - Distractibility
  • P - Painful consequences (Involvement in such activities

Diagnostic criteria

  • Mood Changes: Elation/ irritability
  • Persistently increased Energy

+ ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if irritable mood) for at least 1 week:

 
  • Distractibility.
  • Impulsivity/ high-risk activities
  • Grandiosity/ Inflated Self-Esteem
  • Flight of Ideas (Racing and expansive thoughts)
  • Activity increased (Hyperactivity)
  • Sleep deficit (decreased need for sleep)
  • Talkativeness/ Pressured speech

Management




 

First line

Monotherapy: Lithium, divalproex, and atypical antipsychotics such as olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine, aripiprazole, cariprazine, asenapine, paliperidone, iloperidone, ziprasidone.

Adjunctive therapy with lithium or divalproex:

Risperidone, quetiapine, olanzapine, aripiprazole, asenapine
 

Second line

Monotherapy: Carbamazepine, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), haloperidol.

Combination therapy: Lithium + Divalproex
 

Third line

Monotherapy: Chlorpromazine, Clozapine, Tamoxifen

Combination therapy: lithium or divalproex + haloperidol, lithium + carbamazepine, adjunctive tamoxifen

Mania

Hypomania

Severe symptoms

Less severe symptoms

Duration ≥7 days

Duration ≥4 days

Marked impairment in functioning

No marked impairment

Hospitalisation might be required

No hospitalisation necessitated

Psychotic symptoms can be seen

No psychotic symptoms

Seen in Bipolar I & II

Seen in Bipolar II

questions.text: A child was brought to OPD with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. Whereas laboratory tests revealed normal platelet counts. What will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Henoch-Schonlein purpura

Etiology
  • Most common in males.
  • Exact cause unknown.
  • Immune-mediated vasculitis, often following an upper respiratory infection.
  • Genetic predisposition, with HLA-B34 and DRB1 observed in some cases.

Pathology and Pathophysiology
  • Inflammation of small vessels affecting skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys.
  • Triggered by immune system response to infections.
  • Leakage of fluid and blood cells into tissues.
  • Immune complex deposition, particularly IgA, in affected vessels.

Clinical Features
  • Palpable Purpura: Raised, purplish-red rash, mainly on legs and buttocks
  • Joint Involvement: Joint swelling, commonly in knees and ankles.
  • Abdominal Pain: Often include vomiting, diarrhea, gastrointestinal bleeding, or intussusception.
  • Renal Involvement: Less common, presents as Chronic renal failure.

Diagnosis

Clinical Criteria:

Palpable purpura plus at least one of the following:

  • Diffuse abdominal pain
  • Arthritis or arthralgia
  • Biopsy-proven IgA deposition
  • Renal involvement

Laboratory involvement:

  • Elevated ESR or CRP indicating inflammation.
  • Platelet Counts are normal.

Complications
  • Intussusception.
  • Chronic renal failure due to long term kidney damage, in severe cases.
  • Neurological complications: Rare; may include seizures, headaches, or peripheral neuropathy.

Treatment
  • Mild Cases: Rest, hydration, and pain relievers.
  • Moderate to Severe Cases: Corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) to reduce inflammation.
  • Severe or Resistant Cases: Additional immunosuppressive medications may be required.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present, and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following is a likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Thymoma

Clinical features
  • Mostly asymptomatic (small tumor), incidentally detected.
  • It may compress the trachea (dyspnea), esophagus (dysphagia), recurrent laryngeal nerve (dysphonia or hoarseness of voice), and superior vena cava (superior vena cava syndrome).

Investigations

CT scan
  • Investigation of choice
  • It is used to determine the extent of the disease.

 

Histology (definitive diagnosis)
  • Noninvasive thymomas: Medullary-type epithelial cells (elongated or spindle-shaped) or a mixture of medullary- and cortical-type epithelial cells (admixture of polygonal cortical-type epithelial cells and a denser infiltrate of thymocytes).

 

  • Invasive thymoma: Cytologically benign but locally invasive. The epithelial cells have abundant cytoplasm and rounded vesicular nuclei mixed with numerous thymocytes.
  • Cytokeratin (marker to distinguish thymoma from lymphoma; thymomas are positive for cytokeratin)

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient with a history of spinal tuberculosis was brought to the hospital with low-grade fever, dull backache, and persistent flexion of the hip joint. Hip joint motion was limited and painful. Identify the muscle affected in the CT image.
questions.explanation:
Spinal TB (Pott’s Disease)

Involves lower thoracic and upper lumbar vertebrae in adults; and upper thoracic spine in children.

Lesions spread to adjacent vertebrae and intervertebral disks.

Advanced Disease
  • Collapse of vertebrae leads to kyphosis (gibbus deformity).
  • Paravertebral cold abscesses:
    • Upper spine: Abscess may penetrate the chest wall as a soft tissue mass.
    • Lower spine: May track to the inguinal region or form a psoas abscess.

Diagnosis of Spinal TB
  • Imaging (CT/MRI): Shows characteristic lesions, suggesting TB aetiology.
  • Differential Diagnosis: Includes tumours and infections like pyogenic bacterial osteomyelitis.
  • Confirmation: Aspiration or biopsy confirms TB via positive cultures and typical histology.

Complications
  • Paraplegia: Due to abscess or spinal cord compression; requires emergency drainage if caused by a large abscess.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis, and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed, which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained, and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide?
questions.explanation:
Histopathological features of RHD

Aschoff bodies
  • They are focal areas of inflammation with infiltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells and activated macrophages or histiocytes.
  • An endomyocardial biopsy showing Aschoff's bodies helps in confirming the diagnosis of RHD.

Anitschkow cells
  • They are activated macrophages with elongated and wavy nuclei commonly found within Aschoff bodies.
  • They appear as caterpillars in longitudinal sections (hence also called Caterpillar cells) and owls in cross sections.

Fibrinoid necrosis

This is seen in areas of the valves affected by inflammation.

Granulation tissue is seen in cases of repair. It comprises proliferating blood vessels, inflammatory cells and fibroblasts.

questions.text: A woman with hysteria who was hyperventilating developed carpo-pedal spasms. What could be the likely cause for this?
questions.explanation:
Category

Features

Cause

Neurological
  • Dizziness
  • Mental confusion
  • Paresthesias
  • Circumoral numbness
  • Seizures (severe cases)
  • Due to reduced cerebral blood flow
  • From rapid ↓ PaCO2
  • May occur without hypoxemia

Cardiovascular
  • Chest tightness/pain
  • Palpitations
  • Arrhythmias
  • Possible ECG changes
  • Due to coronary vasoconstriction
  • ↓ ionized calcium effects
  • Bohr effect on O2 delivery

Neuromuscular
  • Carpopedal spasms
  • Tetany
  • Muscle twitching
  • Weakness
  • From ↓ ionized calcium
  • Enhanced nerve excitability
  • Similar to hypocalcemia

Laboratory
  • ↑ pH
  • ↓ PaCO2
  • ↓ Ionized calcium
  • ↓ K+, ↓ PO4
  • Acute: ↓ HCO3- by 2 mEq/L per 10 mmHg ↓ PaCO2
  • Chronic: ↓ HCO3- by 4-5 mEq/L per 10 mmHg ↓ PaCO2
  • Electrolyte shifts into cells

Management

Underlying Disease:

  • Treat primary condition
  • Address anxiety if present
  • Manage sepsis if present
 

Hyperventilation Syndrome:

  • Reassurance
  • Rebreathing techniques
  • Paper bag breathing if needed
  • β-blockers if needed
  • Primary focus on the underlying cause
  • Avoid sedatives for anxiety
  • Monitor during mechanical ventilation
  • Adjust ventilator settings if needed
  • Regular monitoring of blood gases
  • Address psychological factors

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation of the child, the height for the age is < -2 SD according to WHO growth charts. This is most likely due to:

Weight for age is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely underweight

Weight for age is < -3 SD.

Moderately wasted

Weight for length/height is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely wasted

Weight for length/height is < -3 SD.

Moderate Acute Malnutrition
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI for age is between -2 and -3 SD.
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) is between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm.

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) :

 
  • Weight-for-length/height or BMI-for-age is less than -3SDS.
  • MUAC is less than 11.5 cm.
  • The presence of bilateral pitting oedema.

Moderately Stunted (Moderate Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height for age is between -2 and -3 SD.

Severely Stunted (Severe Chronic Malnutrition)

Length/height for age is < -3 SD.

questions.text: A 12-week-old child presented with fever, cyanosis, and fatigue. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation
questions.explanation:
Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

Pathology
  • Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly via an abnormal venous connection
  • Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion

Sites of venous connection
  • Supracardiac- superior vena cava (Most common)
  • Cardiac-coronary sinus, right atrium
  • Infracardiac
  • Mixed

Clinical presentation
  • Cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure
  • With ASD- wide and split S2

Chest X-ray
  • Snowman or figure-8 configuration in supracardiac TAPVC

Treatment
  • Surgery
  • No indication for prostaglandins (Not a ductal-dependent cyanotic lesion)

Correct Answer A - Nephrotic Syndrome:

 

Nephrotic syndrome

Nephritic syndrome (Option B)

Clinical Presentation

Edema, heavy proteinuria

Hematuria, oliguria, edema, hypertension

Proteinuria

Heavy (3+ to 4+) on dipstick

(>3.5gm/24 hour)

(1+ to 2+) levels of proteinuria (<1gm/ 24-hour)

Hematuria

Rare, microscopic hematuria may occur

Common, with cola-colored urine due to gross hematuria

Urinary Casts

Hyaline and granular casts

Red blood cell casts (indicating glomerular inflammation)

Serum Albumin

Low (<1 g/dL)

Usually normal unless severe renal impairment

Blood Urea and Creatinine

Normal unless hypovolemia or acute kidney injury

Elevated due to impaired renal function

Serum Complement C3

Normal

Low in 90% of cases, returns to normal in 8-12 weeks

Cholesterol

Hypercholesterolemia (may cause milky plasma)

No significant hypercholesterolemia

ASO/Anti-DNase B Titers

Not elevated

Elevated ASO titers (pharyngitis) or anti-DNase B (skin infection)

Nephrotic syndrome

Nephritic syndrome
  • Massive proteinuria
  • Lipiduria
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Edema
  • Thrombotic events
  • Mild proteinuria
  • Hypertension
  • Oliguria
  • Hematuria
  • Azotemia

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent retrosternal chest pain, with each episode lasting for 3-5 min and subsiding with sublingual nitrate. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-wave. He has a known case of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia and is currently on aspirin, atenolol, metformin, and lovastatin. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Increase the dose of beta blocker

questions.explanation:
Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: Enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management
  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularisation includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 7-year-old patient who presented with a white pupillary reflex and underwent enucleation, with histopathological examination revealing the presence of Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Retinoblastoma

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific): These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes: These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - MRI

Definition
  • An IOFB is a foreign object that penetrates the eye and remains lodged inside. It is a serious injury that can result in permanent vision loss.

Common Types of IOFBs
  • Metallic (90% of cases): Iron, steel.
  • Others: Glass, stone, lead pellets, copper, aluminium, plastic, wood.

Foreign Body Reactions
  • Inorganic Materials: Glass, plastic are inert; lead, aluminium, copper cause inflammatory responses.
  • Organic Materials: Wood causes giant cell reactions and granulomatous inflammation.

Diagnosis
  • Detailed History: Understand injury mechanism for IOFB type.
  • Ocular Examination:
    • Slit-lamp examination
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy (back of the eye)
  • Signs:
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Corneal scars/ Iris holes
    • Opaque tracks in the lens/ IOFB in vitreous or retina
  • Investigations:
    • X-rays: Less common; CT is preferred.
    • Ultrasonography: B-mode USG locates both radiopaque and non-radiopaque IOFBs.
    • CT Scan: Investigation of choice/ Gold standard for detailed cross-sectional images.
    • MRI: Contra-indicated in case of metal foreign bodies (Option D)

Treatment
  • IOFB Removal: Essential except for inert, sterile IOFBs not affecting vision or if removal is too risky.
    • Magnetic IOFBs: Removed using a handheld electromagnet.
    • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Requires specialized procedures.
  • Removal Methods:
    • Anterior Chamber:
      • Corneal incision, avoiding central cornea.
      • Magnetic IOFBs: Handheld magnet.
      • Non-magnetic IOFBs: Specialized forceps.
    • Iris: Sector iridectomy for IOFBs in the iris.
    • Lens: Extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) with or without lens removal.
    • Vitreous and Retina: Pars plana vitrectomy

Post-Removal Management
  • Topical/systemic antibiotics for infection prevention.
  • Topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.
  • Cycloplegic agents (e.g., atropine) for pupil dilation and pain relief.

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This occurs due to the inhibition of ________ by aspirin.
questions.explanation:
Aspirin

MOA

Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, particularly COX-1 and COX-2. COX-1 is involved in the production of prostaglandins and thromboxane.

Effect on platelets

  • Thromboxane A2 is a potent pro-inflammatory and pro-thrombotic molecule that promotes platelet aggregation and vasoconstriction.
  • By inhibiting COX-1, aspirin reduces the production of thromboxane A2, which leads to decreased platelet aggregation and a reduced tendency for blood clot formation, which can contribute to gastrointestinal bleeding, including the presence of occult blood in the stool.

Uses

  • Analgesic: Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Antipyretic
  • Antiplatelet: Post Myocardial infraction and CVA

Adverse effects

0.5-2 g/day - analgesic dose

  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Epigastric discomfort

3-5 g/day - anti-inflammatory dose

  • Salicylism - vertigo, hyperventilation, tinnitus, reversible loss of hearing
  • Hepatitis
  • Hypersensitivity

Reye’s syndrome: A rare condition seen when salicylates are given in children suffering from viral infections such as influenza, presenting as acute liver failure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a previous history of Colle’s fracture came to the OPD with complaints of lower backache. On evaluation, her T score was -2.5. Which of the following statements about the management of her condition are false?

options.text: Teriparatide should be started before supplementing with bisphosphonates

options.label: B
options.text: Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day

options.label: D
options.text: Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.correct_answer: B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
questions.explanation:
Condition

Role of Bisphosphonates

Osteoporosis

Effective in preventing and treating postmenopausal osteoporosis, age-related, idiopathic, and steroid-induced osteoporosis.

Paget's Disease

Arrest osteolytic lesions, reduce bone pain, and improve secondary symptoms.

Hypercalcemia of Malignancy

Lower serum calcium levels, especially in severe cases.

Metastatic Bone Disease

Arrest osteolytic lesions and reduce bone pain.

Pharmacological Agents

Mechanism of Action

Bisphosphonates

Interfere with osteoclast activity, leading to decreased bone resorption.

Calcitonin

Inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption.

Denosumab

 

It inhibits the RANK ligand, which is essential for osteoclast formation and function.

Estrogen/Raloxifene

Inhibit osteoclast activity and slow bone loss.

Cinacalcet

Indirectly reduces bone resorption by lowering PTH levels.(by stimulating CaSR receptors)

Teriparatide

A recombinant form of PTH stimulates osteoblast activity.

Strontium Ranelate

Dual action: It promotes bone formation by stimulating osteoblasts and decreases bone resorption by inhibiting osteoclast activity.

Calcium and vitamin D

It suppresses bone turnover and improves bone mineral density

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis and difficulty in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Side effects

  • Extrapyramidal symptoms
    • Acute dystonia - occurs shortly after IV injection
    • Parkinson-like symptoms seen after weeks of therapy
    • Irreversible tardive dyskinesia - occurs with chronic treatment
  • Galactorrhoea
  • Methemoglobinemia

Management of extrapyramidal symptoms

  • Discontinuation of the drug.
  • Benzhexol - centrally acting anticholinergic agents.
  • Restores cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.
