questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent a nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient?

Which anti-hypertensive medication is suitable for administration to a patient suffering from renal insufficiency, exhibiting symptoms of significantly reduced urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure reading of 160/90?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Use

Rationale for Choice

Nifedipine

(Short-acting)

Primarily used for angina pectoris.

It is not recommended for long-term hypertension management due to its short duration of action and potential for reflex tachycardia.

Nicardipine

(Short-acting)

It is commonly used in the management of hypertensive emergencies and perioperative hypertension or severe hypertension in the intensive care unit.

The short duration of action makes it less suitable for long-term hypertension management.

Clevidipine

(Ultra-short-acting)

Very short half-life makes it unsuitable for long-term hypertension management.

Amlodipine

(Long-acting)

Recommended as a first-line or add-on therapy for the long-term management of hypertension.

Preferred choice due to its long duration of action (up to 24 hours), once-daily dosing, and effectiveness in lowering blood pressure with good tolerability.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presented with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal oedema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Hepatorenal syndrome
  • Discontinue diuretics
  • Albumin infusion- 1 g/kg per day
  • Vasoconstrictors-Terlipressin, Low-dose Norepinephrine
  • Midodrine (an α-agonist), along with octreotide and intravenous albumin
  • The best therapy for HRS is liver transplantation; recovery of renal function is typical in this setting

questions.text: Evaluation of a patient revealed the presence of a mid-diastolic murmur. JVP showed prominent a-waves. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Tricuspid Stenosis

Aetiology

  • Congenital
  • Rheumatic origin (often coexists with mitral stenosis)

Pathophysiology

  • RA pressure ↑ , due to the diastolic pressure gradient between RA and RV, results in systemic venous congestion.
  • Restricted forward flow of blood leads to ↓ cardiac output.

Clinical features

  • Fatigue
  • Mild dyspnea
  • Venous congestion (right-side heart failure): Hepatomegaly, ascites, oedema and may lead to cardiac cirrhosis.
  • Physical examination:
    • Jugular venous distension with prominent ‘a’ waves
    • Auscultation: Mid-diastolic murmur at left lower sternal border
    • Murmur increases with inspiration (Carvallo's sign).
  • If mitral stenosis coexist
    • Pulmonary artery hypertension
    • Orthopnea due to pulmonary oedema

Investigations

  • Chest X-ray and ECG show features of RA enlargement
  • Echocardiogram: Thickened tricuspid valve with diastolic doming and increased pressure gradient between RV and RA.

Management

  • Medical management: To reduce systemic venous congestion symptoms
    • Dietary salt restriction
    • Loop diuretics
  • Surgical intervention: Valvular repair or Prosthetic valve replacement.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient presents with pain in the thigh during walking. Investigation reveals the following finding as given below. What will be the best surgical management?

A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What is the best agent to prevent future thrombotic events?
Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition mentioned below?

options.label: A
options.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy

options.label: B
options.text: It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.correct_answer: B. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection
questions.explanation:
Definition

Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Cause

It is usually caused by mixed bacterial fora (Escherichia coli, Bacteroides spp., Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus). (Option B)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible oedema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, and erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localised tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism, immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management
  • Initial Treatment:
    • Fluid resuscitation.
    • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
    • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.
  • Additional Measures:
    • Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
    • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
    • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
    • Skin grafting post-infection control.

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy for gallstones 2.5 years ago. She now presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Investigation reveals a stone in the common bile duct. What is the stone most likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Types

  • Retained common bile duct stones
    • Detected within 2 years of cholecystectomy
  • Recurrent common bile duct stones
    • Detected after 2 years of cholecystectomy (Option D)

Clinical features
  • Charcot’s triad : Pain + Fever + Jaundice
  • Reynauld’s pentad: Mental status changes + Hypotension + Charcot’s triad
  • Biliary colic: A sudden, severe, colicky pain in the right upper quadrant that radiates to the back and shoulder, precipitated by a fatty or heavy meal, and can last for a few hours.
  • Darkening of the urine and lightening of the stools.
  • Steatorrhea, or fatty stools
  • Pruritus (itching), loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, and vomiting

Investigation
  • Ultrasound: Useful for detecting gallstones and CBD dilation but has limited sensitivity for CBD stones.
  • MRCP: Non-invasive, excellent for visualising biliary tree anatomy and pathology.
  • ERCP: Highly sensitive, both diagnostic and therapeutic for CBD stones.
  • PTC: Used when ERCP is not feasible, such as post-gastrectomy patients or unsuccessful ERCP attempts.
  • EUS: Invasive but accurate for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.
  • Blood Tests: ↑ bilirubin, ↑alkaline phosphatase, and ↑white blood cell count indicate choledocholithiasis and possible complications like cholangitis.

Treatment
  • Endoscopic Management: ERCP with sphincterotomy and stone extraction; stenting if necessary.
  • Percutaneous Removal: Used when endoscopic access is difficult.
  • Surgery: Options include laparoscopic and open choledocholithotomy, choledochoduodenostomy, and choledochojejunostomy.

Complications
  • Cholangitis
  • Pancreatitis
  • Liver Damage
  • Biliary Stricture
  • Gallstone Ileus

questions.text: A patient arrives after being involved in a motorcycle road traffic accident. The patient does not report any pain or injury. Upon examination, there is evidence of blood at the urethral meatus. What would be your subsequent course of action in terms of managing this patient?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Anterior Urethral Injury

Posterior Urethral Injury

Location
  • Bulbar urethra (most common)
  • Penile urethra

 

 
  • Membranous urethra (bulbomembranous junction most common)
  • Prostatic urethra

Common Causes
  • Straddle injuries
  • Direct trauma
  • Iatrogenic injuries (catheterisation, cystoscopy)
  • Penetrating trauma (stab/gunshot wounds)
  • Pelvic fractures (often due to motor vehicle accidents)
  • Blunt trauma

Clinical Features
  • Hematuria
  • Penile/perineal bruising (butterfly-shaped hematoma)
  • Perineal pain
  • Urinary retention or difficulty voiding
  • Possible swelling of the penis or scrotum due to hematoma
  • Blood at the meatus
  • Inability to void
  • High-riding prostate on rectal exam
  • Perineal or suprapubic pain
  • Pelvic hematoma associated with pelvic fractures
  • Possible concomitant bladder injury

Investigations
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard, shows the extent and location of the injury
  • Voiding Cystourethrography (VCUG): Used to assess urethral patency post-repair
  • Ultrasound: Can detect hematoma or associated injuries
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RGU): Gold standard for initial assessment
  • CT Urethrography: Useful in evaluating complex injuries
  • Pelvic CT Scan: Important for associated pelvic fractures
  • Cystoscopy: Sometimes performed for further evaluation
  • If injury at Prostatomembranous junction - High lying prostate → On IVP- Pie in-sky appearance.

Management

  • Minor Injuries: Managed conservatively with catheterisation or suprapubic catheter if severe bruising
  • Severe Injuries: Surgical intervention like primary repair, urethroplasty, or end-to-end anastomosis
  • Antibiotics: To prevent infection
  • Initial Management: Suprapubic catheterization for urinary diversion
  • Delayed Urethroplasty (Definitive management): 3-6 months post-injury after inflammation and fibrosis have subsided
  • Primary Realignment: Occasionally attempted if conditions permit
  • Endoscopic Realignment: For selected cases, though often reserved for acute management

Complications

  • Urethral stricture (risk of recurrence)
  • Erectile dysfunction (especially if injury near the penile base)
  • Urinary incontinence (less common)
  • Infection (urethritis or abscess formation)
  • Bladder neck contracture
  • Chronic pelvic syndrome

Advantages

Complete

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Incised looking laceration

Types of Laceration

 

Split Laceration (Incised looking laceration)
  • These occur when skin is crushed between two objects, such as the scalp being compressed between the skull and a hard surface like the ground or a blunt object.
  • Seen on areas where the skin is close to bone, with minimal underlying tissue
  • E.g., scalp, eyebrows, cheekbones, jaw, iliac crest, perineum, shin.
  • Lacerations without excessive skin crushing can have sharp edges, resembling incised wounds.
  • Also known as incised looking laceration.
  • These are not undermined and show tissue bridges.

Avulsion (Shearing Laceration)

 
  • Caused by a shearing force at an acute angle, detaching skin or organs from their attachments.
  • The shearing and grinding force from a heavy object, like a lorry wheel passing over a limb, can cause the skin to separate from the underlying tissues, a condition known as avulsion or "flaying."
  • This often results in crushed muscles and fractured bones. The detached skin may have extensive abrasions due to the tyre’s friction, but one portion is still in continuity with adjacent skin.
  • Lacerations from shearing forces can leave the skin intact while separating the underlying soft tissue from the fascia, resulting in a blood-filled pocket. This type of injury is often observed on the back of the thighs in pedestrians hit by motor vehicles.

questions.text: A young teenage boy with a history of drug abuse had been instilled with a shot of intravenous cocaine at a party. He is rushed to the emergency room by his friends. Some of the symptoms were diaphoresis, headache, and acute coronary spasm. Which of the following symptoms noted would go against the likely diagnosis of cocaine poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - Bradycardia

Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless (Option D)
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate (Option B)
  • Increase in temperature (Option C)
  • Rapid and deep respiration

 

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction (Option A)
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted: Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

questions.correct_answer: C. It results due to bacterial activity
questions.explanation:
Marbling

Definition

Refers to a characteristic pattern in the skin caused by decomposition.

Mechanism

After death, bacteria (Option C) spread through blood vessels, decomposing hemoglobin into sulfmethemoglobin (Option B), which causes greenish or reddish-brown staining of the vessel walls.

Pattern

Marbled pattern follows a linear branching pattern, resembling tree branches, which initially appears red and later transitions to a greenish hue.

Onset and Timing
  • Begins to develop 24 hours after death.
  • Becomes prominent by 36-48 hours.

Color Changes Over Time

Skin’s reddish-green marbling may turn dark green or nearly black within 3 to 4 days.

Areas of Marbling

Shoulders, roots of the limbs, thighs, sides of the abdomen, chest, and neck.

Medicolegal Importance

Helps in determining the time since death

Image

Feature

Marbling

Filigree Burns (Option D)

Nature

Postmortem pattern in the skin caused by bacterial decomposition.

Superficial thin, irregular and tortuous skin markings caused by lightning or electrical discharge.

Onset

Starts within 24 hours after death (Option A).

Appears within minutes to an hour of the electrical accident.

Colour

Starts reddish-green and eventually dark green or black.

Red

Site of Occurrence

Blood vessels

Skin surface
